OBJECTIVES
OBJECTIVES
Well 30/8-2 was an exploration well designed to test the hydrocarbon potential of the Tertiary X1 prospect with an expected TD of 2404m RKB in the uppermost Cretaceous. The main target was a prognosed sandy interval within the Lista Formation, (Heimdal Sand).
The objectives of the well were:
1. Prove commercial oil resources in the Heimdal Sand.
2
Clarify the geological model and test the reservoir potential of the Paleocene - Lower Eocene succession.
3
Test the hydrocarbon potential in the north-western part of the licence in order to clarify relinquishment.
4
Have the well approved as the second commitment well.
The well location was selected in order to fulfil the following two criteria:
-
To test an area with a prognosed "thick" reservoir unit and possible high net sand content.
Leave minimum oil resources updip.

RESULTS
RESULTS
The well was spudded 15 December 1995 and reached total depth of 2405m in the Shetland Gp on 29 December 1995. The well was permanently plugged and abandoned as a dry well 16 January 1996.
The main results were as follows:
- The prognosed Heimdal Fm was not present in the well but a sandstone rich interval assigned to the Intra Sele Hermod Formation was encountered. In the Hermod Formation, a total of 31 m net reservoir sand was calculated between 2075,5 mRKB and 2137,5 mRKB.
- The interval 2129 mRKB - 2152 mRKB was cored (2 cores). The cores cover
the lowermost part of the Hermod Fm, basal Sele Fm and the upper part of the Lista Fm.
A Petroleum Geochemistry Study of the reservoir interval indicate that significant amounts of migrated hydrocarbons are detected in the Hermod Fm. Traces of migrated hydrocarbons are detected in thinner sands in Balder Fm and Våle Fm.
The reservoir properties are excellent. An average porosity of approximately 30% has been calculated based on petrophysical evaluation and permeabilities greater than 3500 mD are measured from core plugs. The hydrocarbon saturation is low and no evidence for moveable hydrocarbons was found in the log data.
Details of the petrophysical evaluation are given in the Norsk Hydro's "Formation Evaluation Report, 30/8-2".

BIOSTRATIGRAPHY
BIOSTRATIGRAPHY
The biostratigraphical analysis of well 30/8-2 was carried out by Stratlab. The analysed interval is 1560 - 2405 mRKB (TD). The results are documented in the 30/8-2 Routine Biostratigraphical Report and presented in Fig. 3.1.
The main results of the analysis can be summarised as follows:
- The youngest sediments analysed (at 1560m) are glauconitic sands of the
Hordaland Gp/Grid Formation of Late - ?Middle Eocene age.
- The highest sample analysed giving a definite Middle Eocene age was the
sidewall core at 1659 m within the Upper part of the Grid Formation Fig. 3.1.
- Early Eocene was first seen in the sample at 1930m (SWC).
Late Paleocene (sensu Norsk Hydro) was penetrated at 2115 MRKB within the Hermod Formation. In connection with the transition between the Sele and Lista formations at 2149 mRKB, there is a condensed interval or possibly a stratigraphic break (intra Late Paleocene) in that some biozones are missing.
- The sample at 2357m (SWC) shows that Early Paleocene is penetrated at this
depth.
- At 2367,5 m (SWC) Late Cretaceous (Maastrichtian) sediments of the Shetland
Group are reached. These are the oldest sediments penetrated in this well.

LITHOSTRATIGRAPHY
LITHOSTRATIGRAPHY
All depths are in MMD RKB (RKB is 22m).
This summary is compiled predominantly from ditch cuttings descriptions together with core and sidewall core descriptions. A total of 22 sidewall cores were recovered over the interval 1604m to 2382m. Two conventional cores were cut in the interval from 2129 to 2152m. (Table 6.1).
Wireline and MWD logs were used to aid lithological interpretation and the placement of formation boundaries.
The well was drilled with returns to seabed from the seafloor at 121 m to 1542 m before setting 13 3/8" casing at 1534 m. Lithology interpretation through this interval is based on MWD logs and drilling parameters. The first drill cuttings samples were taken at 1550m.

HYDROCARBON SHOWS
The evaluation of hydrocarbon shows at the wellsite was carried out in a conventional manner. A standard (Baker Hughes Inteq) hydrocarbon total gas detector system together with a gas chromatograph for automatic and continuous gas analysis, recorded as ppm by volume of C1 through nC4, were operational below 1542 m down to the TD of the well.
Hydrocarbon shows on ditch cuttings, cores and sidewall cores were evaluated according to procedures described in Norsk Hydro's "Wellsite Geologist's Manual".

PETROPHYSICAL RESULTS
PETROPHYSICAL RESULTS
No moveable hydrocarbons were identified with this well, although hydrocarbon shows were encountered in the Rogaland Group.
31 metres of net sand was interpreted in the Hermod Formation with a Net Gross ratio of 0.478. No net pay was computed in this formation which was clearly water bearing, in spite of the shows observed. The reservoir properties of the Hermod formation are excellent with an average porosity of 31 p.u. and permeabilities in the Darcy range.
The MDT pressure survey gives a well defined water gradient of 0.99 bar/m throughout the Hermod Fm. This corresponds to a water density of 1.02 g/cc in situ. A very good MDT water sample was obtained at 2123m in the best Hermod sand, consisting according to the water analysis report of formation water, slightly contaminated by mud filtrate. The Hermod Fm. is normally pressured with a pore pressure of 0.99 r.d.
The log quality is in general very good, except for some intervals where the array sonic, the DSI, has shear arrival detection problems due to the very soft formations.
For more details, reference is made to Norsk Hydro report "Formation Evaluation Report, 30/8-2".

GEOPHYSICAL RESULTS
Prognosed and actual time/depth values from well 30/8-2 are listed in Table 9.1 and a time versus depth plot in figure 9.1.
The stratigraphic levels in Palaeocene and Eocene except for Top Balder were encountered within the prognosed uncertainty range and generally on the shallow side. Top Balder was encountered 9,5 m shallower than the uncertainty range. The prognosed Heimdal sand was not present in the well. However, a Top Hermod sand of approximately the same thickness was penetrated 119,5 m shallower.
The picked Top of the Utsira formation on the well logs was 20 m deeper than the prognosed uncertainty range while the Base Utsira were encountered within the uncertainty range.
Base Pleistocene was picked 5 m deeper on the well logs than the prognosed uncertainty range.

Given depth and extent of any gas blanking ("gass-skygging"), seismic anomalies etc.:
Amplitude anomalies were mapped at one level 295 m (326 ms) with a distance of more than 2000 m from the 30/8-2 spud location.
13
Note any indication of gas originating from deeper levels. Give description in cases where gas comes from deeper layers:
How does the interpretation of the site survey correspond to the well data with respect to:
- shallow gas: Indications of gas was observed as low gamma and high
resistivity in a thin sand layer at 386 m. High amplitude anomalies were not mapped in the 30/8-2 area and no gas warning was given for this level.
- sand bodies: The Pleistocene sands correspond in general to the
interpretation. The Pliocene sand layer with indication of gas at 386 m was not predicted. The lower Pliocene sands at 519 m is observed 5 m deeper than predicted. The Top Utsira Fm. is interpreted 40 m deeper than predicted and the base is 15 m deeper than predicted. The depths to the Miocene sand layers observed below the Utsira Fm. (958-1030 m) were not prognosed.
- unconformities: Base Pleistocene is poorly defined, but is picked in the
logs at a maximum gamma event. This event has no corresponding seismic event, but is close a reflector interpreted as an Intra Pliocene horizon at 295 m (326 ms). The Top Utsira Fm. was observed at 640 m (654 ms) and predicted at 605 m (630 ms). The Base Utsira Fm. was predicted at 785 m (813 ms) and observed at 800 m (813 ms).
- correlation to nearby wells: The seismic correlation to tie wells 30/8-15
and 30/5-1 is poor for the Base Pleistocene and Top Utsira Fm. Base Pleistocene is based on a log pick of a maximum gamma event in well 30/8-2. The log event has no corresponding seismic event. The deviation between the prognosed and observed depths for the Top Utsira Fm. is casued by a combination of wrong seismic pick and the use of low velocity in the Pliocene interval.

GENERAL
All depths referenced to RKB, 22 m above MSL. Seabed was located at 121 m.
The semisubmersible drilling rig "West Vanguard" drilled the vertical exploration well 30/8-2. The well started at 11:30 hrs the 14th of Dec 1995 and was finished 33 days later.
POSITIONING AND ANCHORING OF THE RIG
Rig Move and Anchor handling
The navigation and positioning system used were Differential Global Position System (DGPS). For further information, see separate positioning report prepared by Racal Survey Norge A/S.
The final position / co-ordinates of the wellhead (Horizontal Datum: ED50, UTM-ZONE 31 (CM 3* EAST)):
Geographical Latitude: 60° 27'24.51"N. Longitude: 02° 21'47.92" E
UTM 6 702 613.8 mN 464 976.4 mE
The rig heading was 212° The well position was located 11.2 m in a bearing of 178 degrees (UTM Grid) from the intended location.
DRILLING SUMMARY AND EXPERIENCES
36" hole section / 30" conductor
Total depth of section: 182 mMD.
The well was spudded and 36" hole drilled with sea water from 121 m to 182 m, pumping high-viscous bentonite sweeps as required. The drilling rate was slow due to boulders. After a wipertrip the hole was displaced to 1.30 sg mud. The 30" conductor was set at 181 m and cemented.
J:\WELLSITE\3008-19013082\FWRDRILLING.SAM
3.2
17 1/2" hole section / 13 3/8" intermediate casing
Total depth of section; 1542 mMD.
The 17 1/2" hole was drilled with sea water from 182 m to 1542 m, pumping high viscous bentonite sweeps as required.
Observed shallow gas on the MWD log at 420 m, but did not see anything with the ROV.
The hole was displaced to 1.20 sg mud, prior to pulling out of the hole. The 13 3/8" casing was set at 1534 m. A 1.56 sg gasblock cement was pumped between the lead and the tail slurry.
The BOP was installed and tested.
3.3
12 1/4" x 8 1/2" hole section
Total depth of section: 2129 MMD (12 1/4") / 2405 MMD (8 1/2").
The hole was displaced to 1.43 sg KCl mud while drilling the shoetrack. After drilling 3 m of new formation, a formation integrity test to 1.81 sg equivalent mud weight was performed
The 12 1/4" hole was drilled to 2129 m in two bit runs and one bit trip. The first bit, a rerunable PDC, stopped driling in a cemented sand string. After several flowchecks due to drillbreaks a wipertrip to the shoe was performed before pulling out for coring.
Cut 8 1/2" cores from 2129 m to 2152 m in two runs. Did not pass 1610 m in the first run, changed out a 12 1/4" stabilizer to a 12 1/8" before continue running in the hole for cutting of core no. 1.
Core no. 1: 4.5 m (75%) recovery, jammed off after 6 m coring. Core no.2: 16.7 m (98%) recovery..
The cored section was reamed to obtain MWD log.
Drilled the8 1/2" hole from 2152 m to total depth of the well at 2405 m. Some tight hole was experienced on a wipertrip to 2129 m. Reamed the tight interval and the transition interval from 12 1/4" to 8 1/2" holesection.
A total of 5 wireline logs were run. Log no.3 (MDT) had to be run twice due to plugging of the tool. Had problems with the communication from the Schlumberger wireline unit and CGG VSP control unit when running log no.4 (VSP).. Took sidewall cores from 2392 m to 1604 m with log no.5 (CST).
J: WELLSITE\3008-190130821FWRDRILLING. SAM
C-5
3.4
Temporary Plug & Abandonment
Cemented the hole from TD to 1874 mMD in two steps, load tested the plug to 10 tons. Sat a 13 3/8" bridgeplug at 1475 mMD and pressure tested it to 127 bar. Sat a cementplug from top of the bridgeplug and up to 1325 mMD.
Pulled the BOP and riser. Cut the 20" and 30" casing and recovered RGB/wellhead. The anchors were pulled and the rig left the location the 15th of June 1996 at 08:30 hrs after having waited for 263.5 hrs due to bad weather.
